title: Stand-up Comedy and Presentations
subtitle: Monica Platter reflects on how performing comedy helped her improve her workplace presentations.

cards.text: I tend to speak very quickly and run out of things to say, but after a couple of difficult experiences at the club I realised I needed to speak at half the speed. That way I immediately made life easier for myself. ... I've subsequently tried to slow down in the presentations I give at work, and it's definitely helped.
cards.question: Which sentence completes the turning point about slowing down?
choices: It was a major turning point for me.
This showed the importance of observing your audience and responding to them.
It's when your audience has a think about what you've just said.
It felt more like a shaky mess to me than anything else, to be honest.
cards.highlight: It was a major turning point for me.

cards.text: Similarly, in a presentation, if your audience isn't looking excited, it might just be that they don't show much emotion. You might have been good or rubbish up to that point. ... Do that and you'll end up feeling better.
cards.question: Which sentence suggests what to do if the audience doesn’t look engaged?
choices: This showed the importance of observing your audience and responding to them.
Either way, the best thing to do is carry on and assume they're really getting a lot out of it.
It just provides them with an opportunity to remember what they were meant to say next.
It's when your audience has a think about what you've just said.
cards.highlight: Either way, the best thing to do is carry on and assume they're really getting a lot out of it.

cards.text: Every comedian I met at the club said that knowing how to pause is crucial. They get the joke and wait in suspense to find out what comes next. I've realised that the same principle applies to other types of public speaking. It's good to extend your pauses and use them to make your listeners think before you move on. ...
cards.question: Which sentence completes the idea of pauses?
choices: It's when your audience has a think about what you've just said.

It felt more like a shaky mess to me than anything else, to be honest.
It just provides them with an opportunity to remember what they were meant to say next.
cards.highlight: It's when your audience has a think about what you've just said.

cards.text: I would often stand at the club almost fainting with fear, but I managed to deliver a routine that people thought was calm and polished. ... If you appear to be in control, however, people believe that you know what you're doing, and they listen to you.
cards.question: Which sentence adds Monica’s honest reflection about how she felt?
choices: It just provides them with an opportunity to remember what they were meant to say next.
This told me the best script in the world is nothing in the hands of someone who isn't funny in themselves.
It felt more like a shaky mess to me than anything else, to be honest.
This showed the importance of observing your audience and responding to them.
cards.highlight: It felt more like a shaky mess to me than anything else, to be honest.

cards.text: Then, there is the use of fillers, techniques that comedians and public speakers regularly employ. I've seen some take a sip of water, while others adjust the microphone lead, even though they're not thirsty and the microphone sounds fine. ... So, whether you're going to do stand-up or business talks, develop fillers that you feel comfortable with.

cards.text: The bottom line with stand-up comedians, however, is that it's always been about performance and delivery. Everything I saw at the club confirmed that. ... I've been to great shows where 80% of the humour came from the comedian's facial expressions, and eyebrow movements seemed particularly important.
